all_paragraphs: As the COVID-19 pandemic prolonged, the need to re-open the economy is urging. In order to be prepared, surveys that try to determine the prevalence of the disease had been carried out recently. As of 4/25/2020, three COVID-19 antibody surveillance tests had been carried out in the United States:
These numbers are astonishing. They translate into most of us should already have tens of direct acquaintances that have been infected by the COVID-19. Can this be true?

Let’s take a deeper look. The first author of the Santa Clara County survey preprint¹, Eran Bendavid, is an associate professor of medicine at Stanford University. And the LA County survey² is carried out by the University of Southern California. Both are reasonably reputable. However, as of 4/25/2020, the Santa Clara County survey is not peer-reviewed, and the LA County survey doesn’t have a preprint yet. The NY survey has even less information. We know science is about facts, not reputations. So how can we make a quick judgment on the trustworthiness of these numbers?
Let’s first walk through the main idea of the Santa Clara County survey.

The survey tested 3,300 people, and 50 of them turned out to be positive (crude prevalence rate 50/3300 = 1.5%). After adjusting for zip code, race, and sex to be more representative to the county population, they estimated the prevalence to be 2.49%~4.16%. Then they multiply this number by the population of Santa Clara County (~1.9 million) and concluded:
These prevalence estimates represent a range between 48,000 and 81,000 people infected in Santa Clara County by early April, 50-85-fold more than the number of confirmed cases.
Now you can see the preprint basically treat the test positives as if they are infected (real positives). Even though this seems intuitive, is this actually correct? Let’s put it formally,
Given a person is tested positive, what’s the probability of this person being a real positive?
Once we frame the key question, using the Bayes’ rule is simple (“P” means positive, and “N” means negative in the following):

We can expand the denominator by the law of total probability, substituting the above three terms, and then have the posterior estimate:

For the prior, we can use the population prevalence as a starting point. The cumulative confirmed cases in Santa Clara County on 4/3~4/4 is about 1100³. Divided by the county population 1.9 million, we can get the prior of about 0.05%.
Substitute these numbers into equation (1), and we will have
That means, even if a person is tested positive, this person is still most likely negative!
This result may seem counter-intuitive at first, shouldn’t we expect a positive result indicating an infected person?

Here is the key. The confirmed counts that we usually encountered in news is determined by an RNA-based “diagnostic test”, not an antibody-based “surveillance test”. Other than the difference in sensitivity, specificity, and many other aspects, one major difference is in the test participants — the diagnostic test usually requires some reasons to suspect a person is infected, while the surveillance test participants are general public. In mathematical terms, the test participants’ priors are different.
For example, here is the diagnostic test guidance on the Illinois Department of Public Health website (as of 4/26/2020):

Just think about many of your direct friends satisfied these requirements, you can estimate that the prior probability of infected among these diagnostic test participants is probably 100 times higher than the general public. Therefore, a positive test result from a diagnostic test participant indeed most likely indicates a real positive (existence of the virus).

One may argue that the 0.05% prior above is too low because many real infected people didn’t go to tests. This is a valid concern, so we can estimate the prior from a different way. For example, the test positive rate (given symptomatic person) is usually from 10%~30%⁴. If we think a person with symptoms is 50–100 times more likely to be infected, then we can come up with a 0.2%-0.5% prior. But even with a 0.5% prior, the posterior probability given a positive result is only 45%, or about the same as flipping a coin.

Below is a plot of the probability of being a is real positive given a positive test result, at different prior and specificity levels. The prior from the Santa Clara general public is the dotted line on the left, and a prior from the diagnostic test participants would be somewhere on the right. Thus positive results from different participants have very different implications.

Now it’s clear that even if the Santa Clara survey’s sample is representative of the population, its prevalence estimate is likely to be overstated by about 10 times. No wonder this preprint drew lots of criticisms from experts. Just as Andrew Gelman, a statistics and political science professor at Columbia University, wrote on his blog:

“I think the authors of the above-linked paper owe us all an apology …We wasted time and effort discussing this paper whose main selling point was some numbers that were essentially the product of a statistical error.”

For the other two surveys in LA County and in New York State, the lack of information prevents detailed discussions. But from the results, they look similar to the Santa Clara County study. So we should doubt those results until further information is revealed.
One may wonder, given a positive surveillance test result, if that person’s chance of being real positive is so low, then what does the result tell us?
